attributes.title: The effects of self-transcendent experiences on wisdom and epistemic humility
attributes.description: Self-transcendence has been argued to sit at the core of wisdom (Levenson et al., 2005). Self-transcendent experiences (STEs) are comprised of transient mental states of decreased self-salience and increased feelings of unity. Individuals who feel this diminished sense of self as well as a greater concern for others should, then, demonstrate enhanced wise reasoning, but empirical work testing this proposal is yet to be done. Study 1 documents the positive relationships between STEs (awe and flow), in contrast with happiness, and wisdom. Study 2 explores the effects of experimentally induced awe and flow on wisdom and epistemic humility. Implications for future work on STEs and wisdom are discussed.

q1.value: The effects of self-transcendent experiences on wisdom and epistemic humility

q2.value: Yena Kim, Fan Yang, Howard Nusbaum

q3.value: Self-transcendence has been argued to sit at the core of wisdom (Levenson et al., 2005). Self-transcendent experiences (STEs) are comprised of transient mental states of decreased self-salience and increased feelings of unity. Individuals who feel this diminished sense of self, as well as a greater concern for others, should demonstrate enhanced wise reasoning, but empirical work testing this proposal is yet to be done. Study 1 documents the positive relationships between STEs (awe and flow), in contrast with happiness, and wisdom. Study 2 examines the effects of experimentally induced awe and flow on wisdom and epistemic humility. Implications for future work on STEs and wisdom are discussed.

q4.value: We intend to explore whether awe and flow experiences have effects on wisdom and epistemic humility.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between-subjects design with 4 conditions (awe, amusement, flow, control).

q9.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. Random assignment will be done via Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk. Participants must be at least 18 years old and agree to participate.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 240 participants (about 60 participants per condition). We will recruit 15 more participants per condition (75 in total), assuming that not all will complete the study or correctly answer the attention check. The total sample size is 300 participants.

question.value: We will manipulate the experienced emotions of the participants by asking them to do a recall and writing task. Depending on the condition, participants will be asked to recall and write about an event that involved experiences of awe, amusement, flow, or ordinary chores.

We have two dependent variables—wise reasoning and epistemic humility. 

To measure wise reasoning, participants are asked to vividly ponder a difficult interpersonal event. They then answered items assessing wise reasoning. Responses are measured on a scale from 1, not at all, to 7, very much. 

To measure epistemic humility, participants filled out a self-report scale assessing their acknowledgment of the value and contribution of others and outside forces. Responses are measured on a scale from 1, strongly disagree, to 7, strongly agree.

We will conduct linear models to examine whether participants in the four conditions differ in terms of  wise reasoning and epistemic humility: 

Wise reasoning<-lm(response ~ condition, data=data)
Epistemic humility<-lm(response ~ condition, data=data) 

If there is a significant difference between conditions, we will conduct pairwise comparisons using Tukey’s adjustment to examine the differences between different conditions.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining if the linear models and the post-hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were supported. The post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test adjusts for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: Incomplete surveys will be excluded from the analysis. Participants who fail the attention check or who provide invalid responses to the writing prompts will be excluded.

q23.value: Incomplete or missing data will not be analyzed.

q24.value: We may explore whether participants’ rated awe and flow positively predict wise reasoning and epistemic humility, controlling for rated amusement across conditions. We may compare people’s ratings of wise reasoning and epistemic humility in different conditions to the corresponding neutral rating points, as well as explore whether there are correlations between their ratings of the two. We will also be collecting demographic data to be used for exploratory purposes, such as examining the influences of age, gender, race, and educational attainment.

attributes.title: Science Skepticism - The Role of Spirituality and Faith in Intuition
attributes.description: We will investigate whether 'faith in intuition' mediates the relationship between spirituality and general faith in science and vaccine skepticism. The purpose is to explain and expand on work by Rutjens & Van der Lee (2020) which reports evidence of a relationship between spirituality and vaccine skepticism, and general faith in science. We introduce a mediator—faith in intuition—that potentially explains this effect.

q2.value:
Main hypotheses:

H1a: We expect a positive relationship between spirituality and two indicators of science skepticism (i.e., vaccine skepticism and low general faith in science). H1b: We expect that this relationship is mediated by faith in intuition. Specifically, we expect that individuals with higher self-reported spirituality put more faith in their intuitions, and that faith in intuition mediates the relationship described under H1a. 
H2: We do not expect such a relationship for evolution skepticism. Rather, we predict that religiosity, and not spirituality, is the best predictor of evolution skepticism.

Exploratory hypothesis:

H3: We explore the possibility that there is a negative relationship between spirituality and climate change skepticism, which is mediated by faith in intuition. 

Note: We will be recruiting two samples which results in two studies (Study 1a and 1b), this will be explained more later on. Importantly, we formulate the same hypotheses, as stated above, for each of the two samples.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We use a correlational design and develop a questionnaire in Qualtrics in which we ask participants about their opinions and characteristics (see: Materials OSF). We have two samples, one American (MTurk) and one British (Prolific).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect data through two different participant databases, namely Amazon's Mechanical Turk (MTurk), which will result in an American sample, and Prolific, which will result in a British sample. For both databases, we will compensate participants with a monetary reward for their efforts in accordance with the reward standards for these databases. We will aim to recruit 250 participants for each study, resulting in a total of 500 participants. Data collection will start in the second half of April 2020 and is expected to take not more than one week.

q11.value: 250 British participants (Study 1a) and 250 American participants (Study 1b). The samples will be analyzed as separate studies.

question.value:
The definitions of each of the variables come from the way in which they are measured. Therefore, I refer you to the 'Materials OSF_v2' document once more where it is clearly outlined how each variable is measured. 

An overview of the variables:
Dependent measures (4): Faith in science, vaccine/climate change/evolution skepticism
Independent measures (3): Spirituality, religiosity, faith in intuition Demographic measures (7): Political ideology (i.e., liberalism/conservatism), scientific literacy, age, gender, level of scientific training, nationality, ethnicity.

First, we report correlations for all variables of interest. Second, we will conduct several multiple regression analyses, one for each of the four dependent variables. We will include all relevant variables (i.e., independent and control variables) as predictors in the regressions. Third, to test hypothesis 1b and 3, we will conduct mediation analyses using PROCESS by Hayes in SPSS as well as a similar R package (e.g., jamovi). The first mediation analysis will test whether the relationship between spirituality and vaccine skepticism is mediated by faith in intuition (hypothesis 1b). The second mediation analysis will test whether the relationship between spirituality and low general faith in science is mediated by faith in intuition (hypothesis 1b). The third mediation analysis will test whether the negative relationship between spirituality and climate change skepticism is mediated by faith in intuition (hypothesis 3).

q18.value: Some items in the questionnaire need to be reverse-coded. These items are indicated in the "Materials OSF_v2" document with a '*'.

q20.value: We exclude participants who fail to at least one out of the two attention check items (see 'Materials OSF_v2'). In addition, we will exclude participants who complete the questionnaire in under 5 minutes.

q21.value: Missing data is highly unlikely due to the 'Force response' option used in Qualtrics.

q1.value: Alexis Wilkinson, Laura A. King, Jake Womick, Jordan Booker

q2.value:
For self-identified White individuals, imagining oneself as a Black person will result in higher positive responses to health equity attitudes and racial prejudice. Individuals asked to imagine themselves as African American will respond more positively to these outcome measures than white individuals who were asked about their current self or a control topic, a trip to the grocery store. 
This study will test the prediction that White individuals asked to imagine and write a narrative description of their best possible self (BPS) if they were African American will respond more positively to policies directed at reducing health disparities and report lower anti-Black prejudice than White individuals  asked to imagine and write about their current BPS or a control topic, a trip to the grocery store. 

The secondary aim of this study is to examine the narrative responses provided in response to these prompts that might help us to understand what experiences White people imagine African American people to have, and how these imagined experiences relate to their attitudes towards health disparities and racial prejudice. We expect that more thoughtful responses will be associated with more positive responses on the dependent measures.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a between-subjects, randomized block design with counterbalanced dependent variables. Participants will be randomly assigned to one IV condition and will complete all DVs. The dependent variables of health equity attitudes and prejudice will be presented in counterbalanced order after the completion of the narrative portion.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Data will be collected from Amazon Mechanical Turk Workers and from undergraduate students. Turk workers will be compensated $1.00 for completion of the study. Students will receive 1 research credit towards their Psychology 1000 requirements. Participants will all be self-identified as White. Data collection is ongoing (began 4/5/20). The aim is to collect 600 Turk workers, 150 students.

q11.value: We aim for 200 participants per cell in the Turk sample for a total of 600 subjects. We are aiming for 150 students, for a division of 50 per cell.

question.value: Independent variables - condition. Best possible self, best possible black self, control topic. All participants will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions.
health equity attitudes, modern racism, positive affect, ease, vividness, frequency

First, we will subject the health disparities and prejudice measures to a 3(Black BPS, Current BPS, Control) x2(Racism, Health Disparities) ANOVA. If there are no effects of order, it will be dropped as a factor from the rest of our analysis. If there is a condition by order interaction, we will split the file and analyze each order separately, treating the dependent measure. Although we are not expecting an order effect, it is conceivable that having considered one of these topics might affect responses to the other. We are predicting that the Black BPS condition will lead to more positive attitudes towards reducing health disparities and antiblack prejudice compared to the White BPS condition.
We will test our predictions using one-way analyses of variance with three groups then we will run planned contrasts testing the idea that the Black best possible self condition will lead to more positive attitudes toward policies aimed at lowering health disparities and lower prejudice compared to the other two groups. Because of the pandemic context, our control group may not function as expected because going to the grocery store is an unusual event.  
We will also test for the effects of the manipulation on mood and vividness.  We will test both positive mood and vividness as covariates and potential moderators. Specifically, it may be that individuals with more vivid Black possible selves will show the strongest effects. 
We will create a coding scheme for the "Best Possible Self" narratives based on past studies. Those narratives will be coded by individuals blind to the purposes of the study. We will then examine how condition effects these narrative features, and whether narrative difference serve as mediators or moderators of condition effects.

q19.value: We do not plan on making exclusions unless the participant is not self-identified as White. We will also exclude participants who did not respond to the prompts.

q20.value: Yes, an attention check will be included in the context of the survey. Participants who fail this attention check will be excluded from analyses.

q22.value:
We will examine the narratives provided in the two BPS groups and devise a content analytic scheme. All narratives will be coded using dimensions identified in this examination by coders blind to study predictions. We will then examine whether there are differences across the types of BPSs generated for the study. We will also test whether the content of the narratives differs across the conditions and potentially mediates or moderates condition effects on the main outcomes. 

Given that these data are being collected during an ongoing pandemic, it is possible that this context will affect our manipulations. It is widely known that African Americans have been more strongly affected by the pandemic so it may be that people are more sensitive to issues pertaining to this group. It is also possible that our control condition might not function as a true control as many individuals are no longer able to travel to buy groceries in a store. If this is the case, we will drop the control from our planned analysis and do comparisons with the two remaining groups. The "Best Possible Self" manipulation has been known to enhance positive affect, so we are interested in knowing if imagining oneself as another person changes this effect.

The secondary aim of this study is to examine the narrative responses provided in response to these prompts that might help us to understand what experiences White people imagine African American people to have, and how these imagined experiences relate to their attitudes towards health disparities and racial prejudice. We expect that more thoughtful responses will be associated with more positive responses on the dependent measures.
registration_responses.q3: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any human observation of the data
registration_responses.q11: We aim for 200 participants per cell in the Turk sample for a total of 600 subjects. We are aiming for 150 students, for a division of 50 per cell.
registration_responses.q19: We do not plan on making exclusions unless the participant is not self-identified as White. We will also exclude participants who did not respond to the prompts.
registration_responses.q20: Yes, an attention check will be included in the context of the survey. Participants who fail this attention check will be excluded from analyses.
registration_responses.q22:
We will examine the narratives provided in the two BPS groups and devise a content analytic scheme. All narratives will be coded using dimensions identified in this examination by coders blind to study predictions. We will then examine whether there are differences across the types of BPSs generated for the study. We will also test whether the content of the narratives differs across the conditions and potentially mediates or moderates condition effects on the main outcomes. 

Given that these data are being collected during an ongoing pandemic, it is possible that this context will affect our manipulations. It is widely known that African Americans have been more strongly affected by the pandemic so it may be that people are more sensitive to issues pertaining to this group. It is also possible that our control condition might not function as a true control as many individuals are no longer able to travel to buy groceries in a store. If this is the case, we will drop the control from our planned analysis and do comparisons with the two remaining groups. The "Best Possible Self" manipulation has been known to enhance positive affect, so we are interested in knowing if imagining oneself as another person changes this effect.
registration_responses.q6.question: This is a between-subjects, randomized block design with counterbalanced dependent variables. Participants will be randomly assigned to one IV condition and will complete all DVs. The dependent variables of health equity attitudes and prejudice will be presented in counterbalanced order after the completion of the narrative portion.
registration_responses.q10.question: Data will be collected from Amazon Mechanical Turk Workers and from undergraduate students. Turk workers will be compensated $1.00 for completion of the study. Students will receive 1 research credit towards their Psychology 1000 requirements. Participants will all be self-identified as White. Data collection is ongoing (began 4/5/20). The aim is to collect 600 Turk workers, 150 students.
registration_responses.q14.question: Independent variables - condition. Best possible self, best possible black self, control topic. All participants will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions.
registration_responses.q15.question: health equity attitudes, modern racism, positive affect, ease, vividness, frequency
registration_responses.q17.question:
First, we will subject the health disparities and prejudice measures to a 3(Black BPS, Current BPS, Control) x2(Racism, Health Disparities) ANOVA. If there are no effects of order, it will be dropped as a factor from the rest of our analysis. If there is a condition by order interaction, we will split the file and analyze each order separately, treating the dependent measure. Although we are not expecting an order effect, it is conceivable that having considered one of these topics might affect responses to the other. We are predicting that the Black BPS condition will lead to more positive attitudes towards reducing health disparities and antiblack prejudice compared to the White BPS condition.
We will test our predictions using one-way analyses of variance with three groups then we will run planned contrasts testing the idea that the Black best possible self condition will lead to more positive attitudes toward policies aimed at lowering health disparities and lower prejudice compared to the other two groups. Because of the pandemic context, our control group may not function as expected because going to the grocery store is an unusual event.  
We will also test for the effects of the manipulation on mood and vividness.  We will test both positive mood and vividness as covariates and potential moderators. Specifically, it may be that individuals with more vivid Black possible selves will show the strongest effects. 
We will create a coding scheme for the "Best Possible Self" narratives based on past studies. Those narratives will be coded by individuals blind to the purposes of the study. We will then examine how condition effects these narrative features, and whether narrative difference serve as mediators or moderators of condition effects.

attributes.title: Prenatal cannabis exposure in ABCD dataset
attributes.description:
Previously, we studied the relationship between cannabis use and individuals with mood/anxiety disorders using cross-sectional data from the Tulsa 1000 study (Victor et al., 2018). Using that dataset, we found that individuals with mood/anxiety disorders and problematic cannabis use were characterized by (1) attenuated striatal activations during reward anticipation (Spechler et al., in press), and (2)  higher impulsivity measures under periods of urgency (Spechler et al., in-preparation). As those findings were derived from cross-sectional data, we propose to reproduce these effects in children with prenatal cannabis exposure. In  doing so, these findings would help inform causal mechanisms related to cannabis use and associated outcomes.

Spechler et al., in press. "Attenuated Reward Activations Associated with Cannabis Use in Anxious/Depressed Individuals". Translational Psychiatry.

Spechler et al., in preparation. "Multifaceted impulsivity differences in anxious/depressed cannabis users".

q1.value: Philip Spechler, Martin Paulus, Wesley Kurt Thompson

q2.value:
We hypothesize to reproduce the findings from our previous studies.

1.) Children with prenatal cannabis exposure will demonstrate attenuated striatal activations during anticipatory reward processing relative to comparison samples, as measured via the MID task under fMRI. 

2.) Children with prenatal cannabis exposure will demonstrated higher levels of impulsivity under positive and negative urgency relative to comparison samples, as measured via the UPPSP instrument.

3.) Related to #2, we hypothesize that exposed participants will show differences in response inhibitions, as measured via the stop signal task under fMRI.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
A two/three-group within-subjects design will be used to compare children with prenatal cannabis exposure vs. matched controls (vs. healthy controls) on striatal activations during win-anticipation (high-win, low-win, neutral). A similar case-control design will be used to probe for differences on the UPPSP instrument and SST task. 

Matched control subjects will be identified using a propensity score matching procedure. This will be necessary to rigorously account for confounding variables including study site/scanner, sex, BMI, SES, head motion, prenatal alcohol/cigarette exposure, etc.

q7.value: Propensity score-matching will be used to simulate a quasi-randomization of participants to the prenatal exposure group vs. matched controls.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value:
The ABCD data is currently semi-publicly available (https://nda.nih.gov). The baseline ABCD dataset also currently exists on the local data servers at LIBR. Those data have not yet been accessed.

At this time, no analyses have taken place. Only a simple count of the total number of baseline participants with (n=648) and without prenatal cannabis exposure (n=10,834) were queried using the data exploration portal (https://deap.nimhda.org). This was done to probe whether or not a sample of interest was even available in the dataset. Group matching and statistical models will not be executed until after preregistration is complete.

question.value:
The ABCD study is a prospective longitudinal study with yearly assessments. Data collection efforts for ABCD are organized into several data categories. Overviews of neuroimaging data, neuropsychological measures, biospecimens, substance use assessments, and culture and environment are given in the citations below.

Lisdahl, Krista M., et al. "Adolescent brain cognitive development (ABCD) study: Overview of substance use assessment methods." Developmental cognitive neuroscience (2018).

Uban, Kristina A., et al. "Biospecimens and the ABCD Study: Rationale, Methods of Collection, Measurement and Early Data." Developmental cognitive neuroscience (2018).

Casey, B. J., Cannonier, T., Conley, M. I., Cohen, A. O., Barch, D. M., Heitzeg, M. M., ... & Orr, C. A. (2018). The Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study: Imaging Acquisition across 21 Sites. Developmental cognitive neuroscience.

Luciana, M., et al. "Adolescent neurocognitive development and impacts of substance use: Overview of the adolescent brain cognitive development (ABCD) baseline neurocognition battery." Developmental cognitive neuroscience (2018).

Zucker, Robert A., et al. "Assessment of culture and environment in the adolescent brain and cognitive development study: Rationale, description of measures, and early data." Developmental cognitive neuroscience (2018).

q11.value:
Using the data exploration portal (https://deap.nimhda.org), it was found that there was n=648 baseline participants with prenatal cannabis exposure, with a remaining n=10,834 without exposure. Those samples will likely be reduced after excluding for other factors like prenatal alcohol/nicotine use, and assessing quality control metrics on the UPPSP and fMRI data.  

Once the final target sample is identified, a propensity score-matched comparison group will be identified and will be similar in size to the target sample. Additionally, a healthy control group will also be identified.

q12.value: The sample will be limited by nature of the group of interest. All participants with prenatal cannabis exposure and acceptable data will be interrogated.

question.value: N/A

Outcome measures--
MID task regions of interest: Mean activation during reward anticipation in the nucleus accumbens, caudate, and putamen.
UPPSP Instrument
Stop Signal Task regions of interest: Mean activation during stop failure and stop success in the right anterior insula and inferior frontal gyrus.

Predictors/Covariates --
sex, body-mass index, head motion estimates, study site,

1.) A mixed model will be used to evaluate group differences on striatal activations (dependent variable). Group status (exposed, non-exposed comparisons, healthy), condition (high, low, neutral), and nuisance covariates will be modeled as fixed factors. Subject will be modeled as a random factor. Main effects of group, condition, and their interaction will be interrogated.

2.) A mixed model will be used to evaluate group differences on impulsivity personality ( UPPSP measures as dependent variable). Group status (exposed, non-exposed comparisons, healthy), sub-scale (five UPPSP sub-scales), and nuisance covariates will be modeled as fixed factors. Subject will be modeled as a random factor. Main effects of group, condition, and their interaction will be interrogated.

3.) A mixed model will be used to evaluate group differences on stop signal task activations  (dependent variable) for each condition (stop failures; stop success). Group status (exposed, non-exposed comparisons, healthy) and nuisance covariates will be modeled as fixed effects. Subject will be modeled as a random effect. Main effects of group will be interrogated.

4.) Generalized random forests (GRF) will also be used to make quasi-causal inferences. The outcome and predictor variables will remain the same as above. GRF model estimation and parameter tuning will be separated from model evaluation using cross-validation schemes.

attributes.title: Wheelchair basketball injuries: A systematic review
attributes.description: systematic review of major injuries in wheelchair basketball

summary.value:
Objective: To identify through a systematic review the main characteristics of injuries in Wheelchair Basketball (WB). 
Design: Systematic Review of literature.
Data Sources: PubMed, ScinceDirect and Google Scholar.
Eligibility Criteria: Studies were included according to the following criteria: (i) involving wheelchair basketball athletes, (ii) only papers written in English, (iii) presents quantitative data of WB injuries.
Results: We found a total of 516 studies evolving injuries in WB athletes. After removal of duplicated data and applied the exclusion criteria, 8 articles were included in the present review. Shoulder was the most affected body part (N= 60; 22.1%). On the other hand, when divided by body segments, the upper limb was most affected (N = 128; 47.2%), followed by the Head and/or face (N = 53; 19.5%), Trunk (spine and ribs included) (N = 48; 17.8%) and lower limbs (N = 42; 15.5%).  
Summary: WB athletes experience a large amount of injuries with different aetiologies that is mainly linked to biomechanics and sport characteristics. In addition, this review showed that studies on WB injuries present a plurality in how data are related, which makes it difficult to survey information in the area. The results found be used to direct new research and clarify pertinent doubts regarding the sport injuries with higher incidence in WB.

attributes.title: WHICH FILTERS ARE THE MOST USED IN PROCESSING BALANCE ASSESSMENT APPLICATION SIGNS? - SYSTEMATIC LITERATURE REVIEW
attributes.description: a systematic review about signal processing with data collected from mobile devices

summary.value: Inertial measurement sensors show noise in their signals during the data acquisition process, which are usually caused by the instrument itself and / or by external factors. Noises are presented through frequencies that can generate erroneous readings, making the results inaccurate. It is possible to minimize the presence of these noises by applying the signal filtering process. Currently, with the use of mobile device applications for the quantification of movement, one of the main challenges is filtering the signals in a way that the data extracted by these devices is as reliable as possible. One of the most used tests for clinical evaluation is the analysis of static and dynamic posture. Thus, the objective of this work was to carry out a systematic review of the use of filters for the treatment of data collected with mobile devices to assess balance, showing the types of filters most used, the effectiveness of each filter and the best and worst results.

attributes.title: The COVID-19 crisis, stress, mood, and behaviour: an ecological momentary assessment study
attributes.description: This study aims to investigate the effects of the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis on stress, mood, and behaviour using an ecological momentary assessment approach via a smartphone-app. The acute phase of the crisis in the spring of 2020 has been characterised by widespread social and economic disruption as many countries try to reduce the spread of the disease. We will explore the acute effects of the crisis on people’s stress and mood (1), and how these potential changes in stress and mood are linked to four types of behaviours: reward seeking (2), music listening (3), social interactions (4), and prosociality (5).
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

dataCollectionDates.value: Given the potential importance of our findings for the current COVID-19 crisis, we plan to publish a preprint outlining our preliminary findings in May 2020. The complete findings including a comparison of the results from Time 1 and Time 2 are planned to be published in 2021. Data collection is currently ongoing having started on 1st April 2020. We will collect EMA data until the end of April 2020.

question2a.value:
Stress and mood (present in all hypotheses) will be measured as follows:

- stress – this will be measured at each EMA on a unipolar (not at all - very much) visual analog scale (VAS) from 0 to 100. In addition, we will measure hair cortisol from a subset of at least 80 participants (or more depending on availability) in order to collect a biological marker of chronic stress (Stalder & Kirschbaum, 2012). Participants will be instructed to cut several thin strands of  hair near the scalp from the posterior vertex region and send them to our lab. Due to the growth rate of 1 cm per month, we will be able to analyse accumulated hair cortisol for the time period during as well as before the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis, respectively. Hair cortisol will also be collected at follow-up, representing chronic biological stress after termination of the acute crisis. 

- mood – this will be measured using a validated measure of mood for EMA studies (Wilhelm & Schoebi, 2007). This includes six bipolar VAS scales, which map on to three dimensions: calmness, valence, energetic arousal (see Appendix 1).

question2b.value:
***************

(1) Stress, mood and the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis

1A. The acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis will result in increased stress and lower mood

acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis - the crisis surrounding the acute phase of the COVID-19 virus outbreak will act as a naturalistic stressor (Time 1). We define the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis as the period (March and April 2020 in Austria) during which there are government restrictions on:

- people’s ability to leave their homes and interact with people who do not live in their household. In Austria, people are only allowed to leave their homes for the following reasons: to buy food or other essentials (e.g. medicines), help someone, exercise either alone or with people who live in the same household, or to work if it is not possible to work from home. People are also required to keep at least 1 metre between themselves and others when in public (social distancing). 

- the opening of workplaces, places of learning (e.g. kindergartens, schools, universities), shops, restaurants, public spaces, sportsgrounds, and playgrounds. During the study period in Austria all but essential shops and services (e.g. supermarkets, healthcare services) are closed (except for the period April 14 onwards when some shops, e.g. those under 400 m2 were allowed to reopen, but under tight regulations).

We will use a (partial) repeated measures design whereby we will ask the same participants to take part in the study again once the crisis is over (Time 2). We aim for this to be in 12 months when there are no longer the above outlined government restrictions. For example, people can leave their homes, work, study and interact with others as before the crisis. Those participants who took part at Time 1 but who do not take part at Time 2 will be replaced by similar participants to ensure comparable sample sizes. We will ensure that both samples are matched on key demographic variables, such as age, gender, nationality, country of residence, people in the household, and working status (see Appendix 1). 


1B. The effect of the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis on stress and mood will be modulated by the presence of psychiatric symptoms and loneliness

- screening for symptoms of depression, anxiety, generalized anxiety disorder, eating disorder, and alcoholism - modified versions of Patient Health Questionnaire (Spitzer, Kroenke & Williams, 1999) and Structured clinical interview (Wittchen et al., 1997)

- perceived stress - perceived stress scale (Klein et. al., 2016; 10 items)

- loneliness - UCLA Loneliness Scale (Russel, Peplau & Cutrona, 1980; 20 items)


1C. The effect of the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis on stress and mood will be modulated by the people’s attitudes towards the crisis

- risk of infection for self – participants are asked about the probability that you will be infected with the virus within the next two months (VAS definitely not – definitely)

- risk of infection for close other – participants are asked about the probability that a person close to them (e.g. partner, child, parent, good friend) will be infected with the virus within the next two months (VAS definitely not – definitely)

- health risk for self – participants will be asked whether they agree with the statement “I am concerned about the effects of the virus on my health.” (VAS Slider: do not agree at all, strongly agree)

- health risk for close others – participants will be asked whether they agree with the statement – “I am concerned about the impact of the virus on the health of the most important people in my life. (VAS Slider: do not agree at all, strongly agree)

- concern about the financial implications – participants will be asked whether they agree with the statement – “I am concerned about the personal financial implications of the crisis.” (VAS: do not agree at all, strongly agree)

- concern about the social implications - participants will be asked whether they agree with the statement –  “I am concerned about the impact of the crisis on my relationships with the most important people in my life.” (VAS: do not agree at all, strongly agree)     


1D. The effect of the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis on stress and mood will be modulated by demographic information

- Age
- Gender
- Nationality
- Country of residence
- Number of people in the household
- Region
- Caring responsibilities
- Current working situation
- Presence of a mental or neurological disorder (self-reported and through Patient Health Questionnaire, PHQ – Kroenke et al., 1999; and, Structured -Clinical Interview, SKID - Wittchen et. al., 1997)
- Presence of a chronic physical illness
- Presence of an acute physical illness (including COVID-19)
- Socioeconomic status (Kuppuswamy, 2003)

See Appendix 1 and Appendix 2. 

***************

(2) Stress, mood, and reward seeking 

2A. Increased stress and lower mood will be related to increased “wanting” and increased consumption of rewards

- reward consumption – at each EMA participants will be asked to indicate which rewards they have consumed since the last assessment (or since waking if it is the first assessment of the day), such as salty or fatty foods, alcohol, and cigarettes (see Appendix 1 for the full list of the rewards).

- “wanting” - at each EMA, participants will be asked to indicate on a VAS how much they desire to consume the rewards at that moment (see Appendix 1 for the full list of rewards)


2B. Increased stress and lower mood will not be related to changes in the “liking” of rewards

- reward “liking” – if participants indicate that they consumed a reward (e.g. fatty or salty food, alcohol, cigarettes, etc.) during an EMA, for each reward they must indicate how much they enjoyed this reward on a VAS from 0 to 100.


2C The relationship between stress and mood and the consumption of rewards will be modulated by the frequency and nature of social exchanges during the crisis

See 2A and 4A 

***************

(3) Stress, mood, and music listening

3A. Music listening will be related to reduced stress and increased mood and this relationship will be more pronounced during the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis

music listening – at each EMA participants must indicate whether they are currently listening to music (yes/no) or if they have listening to music since the last EMA (or since getting up if it is the first entry of the day)


3B. Musical and situational factors will modulate the relationship between music listening and mood and stress

- Liking of music listening - VAS
- Valence of the music - VAS (sad - happy) 
- Arousal of the music - VAS (calming – energising)
- Main reason for listening to the music: Relaxation / Activation / Distraction / Against boredom / Other reason

***************

(4) Stress, mood, and social interactions

4A. The frequency and nature of social exchanges will be bidirectionally related to reduced stress and improved mood and this relationship will be more pronounced during the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis

- Frequency of social exchanges – at each EMA participants will be asked to indicate the number of social exchanges (of more than 2 minutes) they had since the last EMA (or since waking up)

- Frequency of face-to-face social exchanges – participants will be asked to indicate how many of these social exchanges were in person (“face-to-face”)

- Nature of social exchanges – at each EMA participants will be asked to think about their last social exchange and asked to indicate:
          - the number of people in the exchange (2 people / more than 2 people)
          - who this was with (e.g. partner, child, parent, friend)
          - how close they are to this person (VAS: not close at all  - very close)
          - how pleasant the exchange was (VAS: not pleasant at all - very pleasant)
          - how long is was (e.g. < 5 mins, 5-20 mins, 21-45 mins, > 45 mins)
          - how they communicated (in person, voice call, video call, text-based)


4B. The relationship between stress and mood and social exchanges will be modulated by how much people enjoy socialising and social interactions

The extent to which people enjoy socialising and enjoy social interactions will be measured using the Sociability and Prosocial Interactions subscales from the Social Reward Questionnaire (Foukles et al., 2014) 

***************

(5) Stress, mood, and prosocial behaviour


5A. Stress and mood will be related to changes in prosocial behaviour

- prosocial behaviour – at each EMA participants will be asked whether they supported or helped someone since the last assessment and whether this person lives in their household or not


5B. The relationship between stress and mood and prosocial behaviour will be modulated by trait prosocialness

- prosocialness will be measured with the Prosocial Scale (Caprara et al., 2005)


5C. The relationship between stress and mood and prosocial behaviour will be modulated by effort

- effort – at each EMA if participants reported helping behaviour, they will be asked to indicate how much effort was involved (VAS none - very much)

question10b.value:
We will implement a repeated measures design using an ecological momentary assessment (EMA) approach. Participants will be asked questions multiple times a day about their current stress, mood, and behaviour via a notification from a customised app on their smartphone (https://www.movisens.com/). This allows data to be collected naturalistically as people live their everyday lives (Shiffman et al., 2008). We will collect data 5 times a day on 8 consecutive days both during the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis (Time 1: April 2020) and once the crisis is over (Time 2: in 12 months or longer if necessary). Data will be analysed from 7 full days starting the day after they start the study. Participants are prompted to complete an EMA 4 times per day between (1) 10:00 and 11:00, (2) 11:00 and 14:00, (3) 14:00 and 17:00, (4) 17:00 and 20:00, and, they were also required to self-initiate an (5) assessment before going to bed. Pilot data showed that each assessment took approximately 3 minutes to complete. For a full list of the EMA questions, please see Appendix 1. 

The first time participants open the app, they will also complete a set of questions asking basic demographic information (e.g. age, gender, country of residence; see Appendix 1). The day after completing the EMA (on day 9 of the study), participants will be sent a link to complete a set of online questionnaires (https://www.soscisurvey.de/) assessing a range of individual differences measures (see Appendix 2).

question4b.value: German-speaking, Android smartphone or tablet users. The app is in German and is only compatible with Android devices.

question5b.value: We will collect a convenience sample of German-speaking, Android smartphone or tablet users who are 18 years old or above during the acute time of the COVID-19 crisis and once the crisis is over. This will predominantly be people living in Austria, but we also expect some participants from Germany, Switzerland, and South Tyrol. Participants will be recruited through posting in online forums and groups, local participant databases, and through local and national media.

question6b.value: We used the ema.powercurve function from the R package "EMAtools" (Kleiman, 2017) to estimate the minimum required sample size given 5 entries per day across 7 days. This indicated that to detect a small effect size with a mean completion rate of 75%, we would need a sample of approximately 350 participants assuming 80% power. Please see Appendix 3 for the code and associated graph. Given that not everyone who downloads the study app will complete the study, we will recruit as many participants as possible during the study period to try and achieve the required sample size.

question7b.value: Data collection is currently ongoing having started on 1st April 2020. We will collect EMA data until the end of April 2020. However, if we reach or exceed our required sample size with participants who started the study in the first 10 days of April, we will focus our analysis on this sample (since this was the period of the strictest measures in Austria).

question8b.value: Missing data – EMA studies typically report an average completion rate between 60-90% (Dzubur et al., 2018; Jones et al., 2018; Wen et al., 2017). To try and ensure that the mean completion rate is 75% or above as per the power analysis, we will only include participants in the final analysis who take part in the study for 7 consecutive days and complete at least 50% of the EMA entries. For certain hypotheses, we also require that participants complete the individual differences measures after the EMA period on day 9 of the study.

question1a.value:
All hypotheses are confirmatory unless stated otherwise.

***************

(1) Stress, mood and the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis

1A. The acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis will result in increased stress and lower mood

During the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis people are facing many well-established stressors (Holmes and Rahe, 1967), such as concerns about their own health and the health of family members, disruptions to their employment status and family life, and feelings of uncontrollability and uncertainty about the future. We predict the crisis (and the associated restrictions) will result in lower mood and increased stress, as measured by self report and hair cortisol, compared to at follow up when the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis is over. 

1B. The effect of the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis on stress and mood will be modulated by the presence of psychiatric symptoms and loneliness

We predict that individuals who score high on loneliness and who display symptoms of psychiatric disorders (e.g. chronic stress, depression, anxiety) will be more affected by the crisis in terms of their stress and mood. 

1C. The effect of the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis on stress and mood will be modulated by the people’s attitudes towards the crisis

We predict that people’s perceptions of (1) the risk of infection to themselves, (2) the risk of infection to close others, and, the (3) health, (4) financial, and (5) social consequences of the crisis, will modulate the impact of the crisis on mood and stress. 

1D. The effect of the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis on stress and mood will be modulated by demographic information

We will conduct an exploratory analysis to determine which demographic information (e.g. age, gender, physical and mental health status, number of people in household, country of residence, working situation, socioeconomic status) can best predict those individuals whose stress and mood are most affected by the crisis.

***************

(2) Stress, mood, and reward seeking 

2A. Increased stress and lower mood will be related to increased “wanting” and increased consumption of rewards

Stress results in increased activity in the brain’s dopaminergic “reward system” making rewards more salient (Pruessner et al., 2004). We predict that this will result in increased “wanting” (incentive salience) of rewards, such as high caloric foods, alcohol and other drugs, and will result in those participants reporting more stress also reporting greater reward consumption. 

2B. Increased stress and lower mood will not be related to changes in the “liking” of rewards

Enjoyment (or “liking”) of rewards is mediated by the opioid system and is independent from the “wanting” system, which is mainly controlled by the dopaminergic transmission (Lemmens et al., 2011). Furthermore, it has been shown that stress induces an increase in “wanting” of rewards, which is not followed by a higher pleasurable sensation (Pool et al., 2015). Thus, “liking” (hedonic aspect) of the reward will not be linked to increased stress.

2C The relationship between stress and mood and the consumption of rewards will be modulated by the frequency and nature of social exchanges during the crisis

The frequency and nature of social exchanges will modulate the bidirectional relationship between reward consumption and stress. While rewards in general could temporarily relieve stress created by social deprivation, social exchanges can address an underlying unmet need (Matthews & Tye, 2019) and thus “buffer” the effects of stress on consumption of other rewards. We further expect that the size of this effect will depend on the medium (face-to-face, video/audio call or texting) and the valence of the social exchanges. 

***************

(3) Stress, mood, and music listening

3A. Music listening will be related to reduced stress and increased mood and this relationship will be more pronounced during the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis

We predict that music listening will be related to increased mood (valence, calmness, energetic arousal) and reduced stress levels (Groarke & Hogan, 2019; Helsing et al., 2016; Linnemann et al., 2015). During the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis there will be reduced access to other forms of stress regulation (e.g. social support, outdoor activities) so the relationship between music listening and reduced stress and increased mood will be stronger during this period than at follow up when the crisis is over.

3B. Musical and situational factors will modulate the relationship between music listening and mood and stress

Personal, musical, and situational factors should be considered when examining the health benefits of music (Juslin et al., 2008; Linnemann et al., 2018; Linnemann et al., 2015; Randall & Rickard, 2017). We predict that musical factors (valence, arousal) and situational factors (reasons for music listening, duration of music listening, liking of music listening) will modulate the relationship between music listening and mood and stress.

***************

(4) Stress, mood, and social interactions

4A. The frequency and nature of social exchanges will be bidirectionally related to reduced stress and improved mood and this relationship will be more pronounced during the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis

Social contact and social support have been shown to buffer the effects of adverse events on stress and mood (Lin, Dean & Ensel, 2013). We predict that more frequent social exchanges will be bidirectionally related to reduced stress and improved mood. Second, we predict that the nature of these social exchanges, such as their medium (e.g. face-to-face, audio, text; Dunbar, 2012), valence (positive, negative), and who they were with (e.g. family, stranger), will also be bidirectionally related to stress and mood. We predict that during the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis the relationship between social exchanges and altered stress and mood will be stronger than at follow up, as during the corona-crisis many people’s opportunities for social interaction will be limited or disrupted. Thus, the stress buffering effects of social interactions will be stronger.

4B. The relationship between stress and mood and social exchanges will be modulated by how much people enjoy socialising and social interactions

The relationship between stress and mood and social exchanges will be modulated by how much people enjoy socialising (e.g. spending time with others, going to parties) and having kind, reciprocal relationships (Foukles et al., 2014). That is, the stress buffering effects of social exchanges will be strongest in those who find social interaction and socialising more rewarding. 

***************

(5) Stress, mood, and prosocial behaviour

5A. Stress and mood will be related to changes in prosocial behaviour

For this hypothesis we will pit two theories against each other. The “fight or flight” hypothesis argues that stress can lead to an increased urge to self-preserve resulting in reduced prosocial behaviour (Mawson, 2005). Whereas, the “tend and befriend” hypothesis argues that stress can have prosocial consequences (e.g. increased helping) and this increased prosociality reduces individuals’ own stress and improves their mood (Taylor et al., 2000) - thus, the relationship between stress and mood and prosocial behaviour is bidirectional. Both extremes in prosociality have been reported in the media during the crisis (e.g. “panic buying” vs. helping elderly neighbours).

5B. The relationship between stress and mood and prosocial behaviour will be modulated by trait prosocialness

People’s reactions towards others during the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis will vary. One explanation for this could be that stress precipitates habitual behaviours (Schwabe and Wolf, 2009). We predict that individuals who score high on trait prosocialness (Caprara et al., 2005), for whom prosocial behaviour is a “default”, will show an increase in prosocial behaviour when stressed.

5C. The relationship between stress and mood and prosocial behaviour will be modulated by effort

Previous studies have shown that stress can lead to increased prosociality, such as more sharing with others (van Dawans et al., 2012). However, in such studies, participants did not need to exert any significant effort to help another person. Prosocial behaviour reduces when we need to exert significant effort to help others (Lockwood et al., 2017). We predict that, if stress and mood changes lead to increased prosocial behaviour, this will only hold for behaviour associated with low effort.


******************************************

Exploratory analyses

We also pursue several exploratory questions:

(1) The Inclusion of Other in the Self Scale (IOS; Aron et. al., 1992) will measure how connected participants feel to the person they feel closest to and whether this person lives in the same household as them. We aim to investigate, whether:
- there are differences in how connected participants feel towards this person during and after the crisis
- this feeling is modulated by different levels of proximity (e.g., same household during the self-isolation, same household without self-isolation, not the same household) 
- certain individual differences measures can predict these outcomes 

(2) With the Inclusion of Community in the Self Scale (ICS; Mashek et al., 2007) we want to investigate the fluidity of “self” and “the community”-connectedness during and after the crisis. For example, do participants will feel more connected to the worldwide population during the crisis compared to after? We will conduct an exploratory analysis to investigate which factors predict ICS scores.

(3) Following the EMA period participants will complete a post-monitoring questionnaire, which asks participants how they coped with the study and any difficulties they encountered. As we are conducting a large EMA study, we will conduct an exploratory analysis to see whether demographic information is related to difficulties associated with the completion of the EMA. 

(4) We will conduct an exploratory analysis to investigate the relationship between the size of participants’ social networks (i.e. the number of friends they report having; see Appendix 2) and their stress and mood during and after the crisis.

question3a.value: The acute phase of the COVID-19 virus outbreak will act as a naturalistic stressor. Self report and a biological marker of stress will be used to check this manipulation (outlined in further detail below).

question2c.value: Multilevel models will be used to test the above hypotheses as participants will complete multiple assessments (repeated measures) and the data will be nested (e.g. within participant). Multilevel models also allow for unequal data between different participants due to missing entries (Hayes, 2006). For all tests, the inference criteria will be set at p < .05 (two-tailed), unless there are specific directional hypotheses.

registration_responses.dataCollectionDates: Given the potential importance of our findings for the current COVID-19 crisis, we plan to publish a preprint outlining our preliminary findings in May 2020. The complete findings including a comparison of the results from Time 1 and Time 2 are planned to be published in 2021. Data collection is currently ongoing having started on 1st April 2020. We will collect EMA data until the end of April 2020.

registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: The acute phase of the COVID-19 virus outbreak will act as a naturalistic stressor. Self report and a biological marker of stress will be used to check this manipulation (outlined in further detail below).
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
Stress and mood (present in all hypotheses) will be measured as follows:

- stress – this will be measured at each EMA on a unipolar (not at all - very much) visual analog scale (VAS) from 0 to 100. In addition, we will measure hair cortisol from a subset of at least 80 participants (or more depending on availability) in order to collect a biological marker of chronic stress (Stalder & Kirschbaum, 2012). Participants will be instructed to cut several thin strands of  hair near the scalp from the posterior vertex region and send them to our lab. Due to the growth rate of 1 cm per month, we will be able to analyse accumulated hair cortisol for the time period during as well as before the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis, respectively. Hair cortisol will also be collected at follow-up, representing chronic biological stress after termination of the acute crisis. 

- mood – this will be measured using a validated measure of mood for EMA studies (Wilhelm & Schoebi, 2007). This includes six bipolar VAS scales, which map on to three dimensions: calmness, valence, energetic arousal (see Appendix 1).
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
***************

(1) Stress, mood and the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis

1A. The acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis will result in increased stress and lower mood

acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis - the crisis surrounding the acute phase of the COVID-19 virus outbreak will act as a naturalistic stressor (Time 1). We define the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis as the period (March and April 2020 in Austria) during which there are government restrictions on:

- people’s ability to leave their homes and interact with people who do not live in their household. In Austria, people are only allowed to leave their homes for the following reasons: to buy food or other essentials (e.g. medicines), help someone, exercise either alone or with people who live in the same household, or to work if it is not possible to work from home. People are also required to keep at least 1 metre between themselves and others when in public (social distancing). 

- the opening of workplaces, places of learning (e.g. kindergartens, schools, universities), shops, restaurants, public spaces, sportsgrounds, and playgrounds. During the study period in Austria all but essential shops and services (e.g. supermarkets, healthcare services) are closed (except for the period April 14 onwards when some shops, e.g. those under 400 m2 were allowed to reopen, but under tight regulations).

We will use a (partial) repeated measures design whereby we will ask the same participants to take part in the study again once the crisis is over (Time 2). We aim for this to be in 12 months when there are no longer the above outlined government restrictions. For example, people can leave their homes, work, study and interact with others as before the crisis. Those participants who took part at Time 1 but who do not take part at Time 2 will be replaced by similar participants to ensure comparable sample sizes. We will ensure that both samples are matched on key demographic variables, such as age, gender, nationality, country of residence, people in the household, and working status (see Appendix 1). 


1B. The effect of the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis on stress and mood will be modulated by the presence of psychiatric symptoms and loneliness

- screening for symptoms of depression, anxiety, generalized anxiety disorder, eating disorder, and alcoholism - modified versions of Patient Health Questionnaire (Spitzer, Kroenke & Williams, 1999) and Structured clinical interview (Wittchen et al., 1997)

- perceived stress - perceived stress scale (Klein et. al., 2016; 10 items)

- loneliness - UCLA Loneliness Scale (Russel, Peplau & Cutrona, 1980; 20 items)


1C. The effect of the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis on stress and mood will be modulated by the people’s attitudes towards the crisis

- risk of infection for self – participants are asked about the probability that you will be infected with the virus within the next two months (VAS definitely not – definitely)

- risk of infection for close other – participants are asked about the probability that a person close to them (e.g. partner, child, parent, good friend) will be infected with the virus within the next two months (VAS definitely not – definitely)

- health risk for self – participants will be asked whether they agree with the statement “I am concerned about the effects of the virus on my health.” (VAS Slider: do not agree at all, strongly agree)

- health risk for close others – participants will be asked whether they agree with the statement – “I am concerned about the impact of the virus on the health of the most important people in my life. (VAS Slider: do not agree at all, strongly agree)

- concern about the financial implications – participants will be asked whether they agree with the statement – “I am concerned about the personal financial implications of the crisis.” (VAS: do not agree at all, strongly agree)

- concern about the social implications - participants will be asked whether they agree with the statement –  “I am concerned about the impact of the crisis on my relationships with the most important people in my life.” (VAS: do not agree at all, strongly agree)     


1D. The effect of the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis on stress and mood will be modulated by demographic information

- Age
- Gender
- Nationality
- Country of residence
- Number of people in the household
- Region
- Caring responsibilities
- Current working situation
- Presence of a mental or neurological disorder (self-reported and through Patient Health Questionnaire, PHQ – Kroenke et al., 1999; and, Structured -Clinical Interview, SKID - Wittchen et. al., 1997)
- Presence of a chronic physical illness
- Presence of an acute physical illness (including COVID-19)
- Socioeconomic status (Kuppuswamy, 2003)

See Appendix 1 and Appendix 2. 

***************

(2) Stress, mood, and reward seeking 

2A. Increased stress and lower mood will be related to increased “wanting” and increased consumption of rewards

- reward consumption – at each EMA participants will be asked to indicate which rewards they have consumed since the last assessment (or since waking if it is the first assessment of the day), such as salty or fatty foods, alcohol, and cigarettes (see Appendix 1 for the full list of the rewards).

- “wanting” - at each EMA, participants will be asked to indicate on a VAS how much they desire to consume the rewards at that moment (see Appendix 1 for the full list of rewards)


2B. Increased stress and lower mood will not be related to changes in the “liking” of rewards

- reward “liking” – if participants indicate that they consumed a reward (e.g. fatty or salty food, alcohol, cigarettes, etc.) during an EMA, for each reward they must indicate how much they enjoyed this reward on a VAS from 0 to 100.


2C The relationship between stress and mood and the consumption of rewards will be modulated by the frequency and nature of social exchanges during the crisis

See 2A and 4A 

***************

(3) Stress, mood, and music listening

3A. Music listening will be related to reduced stress and increased mood and this relationship will be more pronounced during the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis

music listening – at each EMA participants must indicate whether they are currently listening to music (yes/no) or if they have listening to music since the last EMA (or since getting up if it is the first entry of the day)


3B. Musical and situational factors will modulate the relationship between music listening and mood and stress

- Liking of music listening - VAS
- Valence of the music - VAS (sad - happy) 
- Arousal of the music - VAS (calming – energising)
- Main reason for listening to the music: Relaxation / Activation / Distraction / Against boredom / Other reason

***************

(4) Stress, mood, and social interactions

4A. The frequency and nature of social exchanges will be bidirectionally related to reduced stress and improved mood and this relationship will be more pronounced during the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis

- Frequency of social exchanges – at each EMA participants will be asked to indicate the number of social exchanges (of more than 2 minutes) they had since the last EMA (or since waking up)

- Frequency of face-to-face social exchanges – participants will be asked to indicate how many of these social exchanges were in person (“face-to-face”)

- Nature of social exchanges – at each EMA participants will be asked to think about their last social exchange and asked to indicate:
          - the number of people in the exchange (2 people / more than 2 people)
          - who this was with (e.g. partner, child, parent, friend)
          - how close they are to this person (VAS: not close at all  - very close)
          - how pleasant the exchange was (VAS: not pleasant at all - very pleasant)
          - how long is was (e.g. < 5 mins, 5-20 mins, 21-45 mins, > 45 mins)
          - how they communicated (in person, voice call, video call, text-based)


4B. The relationship between stress and mood and social exchanges will be modulated by how much people enjoy socialising and social interactions

The extent to which people enjoy socialising and enjoy social interactions will be measured using the Sociability and Prosocial Interactions subscales from the Social Reward Questionnaire (Foukles et al., 2014) 

***************

(5) Stress, mood, and prosocial behaviour


5A. Stress and mood will be related to changes in prosocial behaviour

- prosocial behaviour – at each EMA participants will be asked whether they supported or helped someone since the last assessment and whether this person lives in their household or not


5B. The relationship between stress and mood and prosocial behaviour will be modulated by trait prosocialness

- prosocialness will be measured with the Prosocial Scale (Caprara et al., 2005)


5C. The relationship between stress and mood and prosocial behaviour will be modulated by effort

- effort – at each EMA if participants reported helping behaviour, they will be asked to indicate how much effort was involved (VAS none - very much)
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
We will implement a repeated measures design using an ecological momentary assessment (EMA) approach. Participants will be asked questions multiple times a day about their current stress, mood, and behaviour via a notification from a customised app on their smartphone (https://www.movisens.com/). This allows data to be collected naturalistically as people live their everyday lives (Shiffman et al., 2008). We will collect data 5 times a day on 8 consecutive days both during the acute phase of the COVID-19 crisis (Time 1: April 2020) and once the crisis is over (Time 2: in 12 months or longer if necessary). Data will be analysed from 7 full days starting the day after they start the study. Participants are prompted to complete an EMA 4 times per day between (1) 10:00 and 11:00, (2) 11:00 and 14:00, (3) 14:00 and 17:00, (4) 17:00 and 20:00, and, they were also required to self-initiate an (5) assessment before going to bed. Pilot data showed that each assessment took approximately 3 minutes to complete. For a full list of the EMA questions, please see Appendix 1. 

The first time participants open the app, they will also complete a set of questions asking basic demographic information (e.g. age, gender, country of residence; see Appendix 1). The day after completing the EMA (on day 9 of the study), participants will be sent a link to complete a set of online questionnaires (https://www.soscisurvey.de/) assessing a range of individual differences measures (see Appendix 2).
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: Multilevel models will be used to test the above hypotheses as participants will complete multiple assessments (repeated measures) and the data will be nested (e.g. within participant). Multilevel models also allow for unequal data between different participants due to missing entries (Hayes, 2006). For all tests, the inference criteria will be set at p < .05 (two-tailed), unless there are specific directional hypotheses.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: German-speaking, Android smartphone or tablet users. The app is in German and is only compatible with Android devices.

We will collect a convenience sample of German-speaking, Android smartphone or tablet users who are 18 years old or above during the acute time of the COVID-19 crisis and once the crisis is over. This will predominantly be people living in Austria, but we also expect some participants from Germany, Switzerland, and South Tyrol. Participants will be recruited through posting in online forums and groups, local participant databases, and through local and national media.

We used the ema.powercurve function from the R package "EMAtools" (Kleiman, 2017) to estimate the minimum required sample size given 5 entries per day across 7 days. This indicated that to detect a small effect size with a mean completion rate of 75%, we would need a sample of approximately 350 participants assuming 80% power. Please see Appendix 3 for the code and associated graph. Given that not everyone who downloads the study app will complete the study, we will recruit as many participants as possible during the study period to try and achieve the required sample size.

Data collection is currently ongoing having started on 1st April 2020. We will collect EMA data until the end of April 2020. However, if we reach or exceed our required sample size with participants who started the study in the first 10 days of April, we will focus our analysis on this sample (since this was the period of the strictest measures in Austria).
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: Missing data – EMA studies typically report an average completion rate between 60-90% (Dzubur et al., 2018; Jones et al., 2018; Wen et al., 2017). To try and ensure that the mean completion rate is 75% or above as per the power analysis, we will only include participants in the final analysis who take part in the study for 7 consecutive days and complete at least 50% of the EMA entries. For certain hypotheses, we also require that participants complete the individual differences measures after the EMA period on day 9 of the study.

attributes.title: Relations between personality profiles and character strengths - an application of profile analysis via multidimensional scaling techniques (PAMS)
attributes.description: This study aims to apply profile analysis via multidimensional scaling (PAMS; Davison, Kim, & Ding, 2001) to identify latent profiles of personality traits measured by the Big Five Aspect Scales (BFAS; DeYoung, Quilty, & Peterson, 2007) and to examine the associations between these personality profiles and the character strengths measured by the Values in Action Inventory of Strength (VIA-IS; Peterson & Seligman, 2004).
